newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada takes province to court over U.S. salmon spat.
newsitem.headline: Canada takes province to court over U.S. salmon spat.

text.p: The Canadian government said on Thursday it was taking British Columbia to court to make sure the province did not close the Nanoose Bay torpedo testing range used by the United States.
British Columbia has threatened to close down Nanoose Bay to force the Canadian and U.S. governments to reach an agreement on how to divide up Pacific salmon.
"The province has failed to act reasonably and in good faith by exercising its discretion to cancel the sea bed license," the federal government said in a statement.
British Columbia officials were not immediately available for comment.

Ottawa said it began legal proceedings on Thursday in the Supreme Court of British Columbia, asking the court to declare invalid the province's decision to withdraw the license permitting torpedo testing at Nanoose Bay on Aug. 21.
Negotiations between Canada and the United States to establish salmon quotas collapsed in June.
British Columbia Premier Glen Clark then announced that he would withdraw the Nanoose Bay lease unless the two countries reached an agreement or developed a process to reach a deal.
Although both countries have named new negotiators in the dispute and Canada's Fisheries Minister David Anderson has asked Clark to withdraw his threat, Clark has not budged.
Ottawa has been struggling to defuse tensions with the United States over salmon since Canadian fishermen blockaded an Alaskan ferry for three days last month and angry fishermen burned a U.S. flag.
